Graphical abstract The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs modified separator not only can effectively restrict the shuttle effect of polysulfides by physical confinement, chemical adsorption, but also can catalyze the reversible conversion of polysulfides. The polysulfides shuttle effect, sluggish sulfur redox kinetics and the corrosion of the Li anode have become important factors limiting the commercial application of lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). Herein, the polyoxometalate (POM) nanoclusters with high catalytic activity and cobalt selenide with strong polarity are initially complemented to construct a PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs multifunctional separator that can simultaneously solve the above problems. A series of experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the Keggin-type POM, H3PMo12O40·nH2O (PMo12) nanoclusters could function as catalytic centers for sulfur-involved transformations, with the CoSe2 nanoparticles serving as adsorption sites for soluble polysulfides. Accordingly, the assembled battery with the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs modified separator achieves an initial discharge capacity of 1263.79 mA h g−1, maintaining 635.77 mA h g−1, with a capacity decay rate of 0.06% per cycle after 500 cycles at 3C. This work provides a strategic approach for incorporating POM nanoclusters with polar periodic nanomaterials in LSB separators, contributing to the development of multifunctional separator materials, thus promoting the advancement of energy storage systems. Keywords Polyoxometalate Cobalt selenide Multifunctional separator Polysulfides adsorption and catalysis Lithium-sulfur batteries 1 Introduction In the context of escalating demand for scalable energy storage solutions pertinent to portable electronics and electric vehicles, the evolution of sustainable energy storage systems holds paramount importance across various industrial sectors [1–5]. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have gained prominence as an advanced, efficient electrochemical storage technology, capturing the research community's interest due to their superior theoretical specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1), exceptional theoretical energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), cost-effectiveness, widespread availability, minimal toxicity, and ecological compatibility [6–12]. Despite these advantages, the commercial deployment of LSBs encounters substantial challenges. The insulating characteristics of the lithium sulfide discharge by-products (Li2S2 and Li2S) significantly impede redox kinetics [13–16]. Concurrently, issues such as the shuttle phenomenon stemming from soluble intermediates, and the volumetric expansion of sulfur during charging and discharging phases, further diminish sulfur utilization. The above issues would lead to swift decline in specific capacity and deteriorates cycle stability [17–19]. Moreover, the non-uniform plating/stripping of lithium ions contributes to the formation of dendrites, which pose a risk of breaching the separator and instigating internal short circuits within the battery [20]. To resolve above challenges, a range of strategies has been applied to optimize sulfur electrochemistry, such as incorporating conductive host materials, binders, and functional separators [21,22]. The introduction of functional separators is considered one of the most promising strategies for blocking polysulfide migration without hindering Li+ transport. Currently, the most common material used for separator is polypropylene (PP), which finds extensive applications in various types of batteries [23–25]. However, PP separators are not suitable for long-cycle LSBs due to their inadequacy in effectively mitigating the shuttle effect associated with lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), caused by weak interactions between PP and LiPSs [26–28]. In recent years, extensive efforts have been undertaken to address this challenge by modifying PP separators using carbon materials [29,30], transition metal-based compounds [31,32], conductive polymers [33] and metal–organic frameworks [34]. Although these functionalized PP separators could enhance the performance of LSBs, there is still great room for improvement in long-term cycle stability due to the sluggish kinetics of polysulfide conversion. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a class of anionic inorganic oxygen clusters based on transition metals such as Mo, W, V, Nb, etc., which possess unique multi-electron storage capabilities, strong redox properties and outstanding stability during electrochemical process [35–39]. Owing to these characteristics, POMs have been widely explored as optional electron reservoir and redox accelerator to boost activity in a variety of electro-catalytic reactions [40–46]. In recent years, POMs have been directly involved in the LSBs system as clusters-based catalyst to boost the rapid conversion between Li2S/Li2S2 and LiPSs. K3[H3AgIPW11O39] [47], rGO-CNT/PW12 [48] and [Co4(H2O)2(PW9O34)2]10/rGO [49] were successively employed as sulfur cathode host materials and catalysts. Lately, [PW12O40]3−/Super P [50], [Zn2(H2O)3)(WO2)2(SbW9O33)2]10@2CD [51], P2Mo18 [52], PMo12@CNT [53] and KPW/GO [43] were successfully developed for separator modification to enhance the redox kinetics. We note that the current researches on the application of POM cluster materials in LSBs mainly focus on the POM-based crystalline materials and the composites of POM and non-polar carbon materials. As known to all, the electrical conductivity of POM cluster is relatively poor, and the adsorption capacity of non-polar carbon material to soluble polysulfides is very limited. Therefore, the developed POM-based materials up to now are still not efficient enough in fixing and boosting the conversion of polysulfides. Inspired by the above discussions, we envisage combining a material with strong polarity and good conductivity with POM clusters to achieve a synergistic and complementary effect. Periodic cobalt selenide (CoSe2) entered our field of vision due to its strong polarity, unique sulfurophilic ability and semiconductor property. It has been demonstrated that CoSe2 can impede the LiPSs migration via strong chemical adsorption, thus alleviating the nasty shuttle effect [54–56]. If the proposed POM/CoSe2 composite can be successfully obtained, there exists the great potential for a simultaneous significant enhancement in the anchor and catalytic conversion of LiPSs due to the excellent adsorption capacity of CoSe2 for polysulfides and the outstanding catalytic ability of POM clusters between short-chain polysulfides and long-chain polysulfides. However, to the best of our knowledge, the exploration of composites of POM clusters and periodic materials including CoSe2 in LSBs is still blank. Herein, the classic Keggin-type H3PMo12O40·nH2O (PMo12) POM nano-clusters was firstly combined with CoSe2 to obtain PMo12/CoSe2 composites and applied as modified separator materials in LSBs. Additionally, to further improve the electrical conductivity and physical limiting ability towards LiPSs, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were also introduced into the above PMo12/CoSe2 system [57,58]. The composite material of CNTs connected to nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) that encapsulates CoSe2 nanoparticles and PMo12 nanoclusters, namely PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, was synthesized by selenizing the composite of ZIF-67/CNTs, and then loading PMo12 nano-clusters on their surfaces and/or cavities. Thanks to this design scheme, with the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP modified separator, the initial discharge specific capacity of the LSB can reach 1263.79 mA h g−1 under 0.1C (1C equals 1675 mA h g−1) condition, and exhibits a long cycle life (capacity decay of 0.06% per cycle at 3.0C for 500 cycles). The synergistic effect between two components of PMo12 nanoclusters and CoSe2 nanoparticles during the battery cycle was elucidated by a series of spectroscopic technologies, in situ electrochemical characterizations and theoretical calculations. This study provides a certain reference for the future application of POMs clusters and periodic nanomaterial composites in improving the performance in LSBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of ZIF-67/CNTs and CoSe2@NC/CNTs The detailed procedures are provided in the experimental section of the Supporting Information. 2.2 Synthesis of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs The 0.1 g of CoSe2@NC/CNTs precursor prepared by the aforementioned process was dispersed in 40 mL of water and stirred at room temperature for 1 h to form a homogeneous black mixture. Then, 0.2 g of PMo12 dispersion (in 20 mL deionized water) was added to the 40 mL of the above homogeneous mixture. The reaction mixture thus obtained was subsequently transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave constructed of stainless steel and subjected to a thermal treatment at 120 °C for a duration of 8 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the resultant product underwent multiple washing cycles with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h to gain pure and dry PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. 2.3 Preparation of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP functional separators The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PVDF were separately dissolved in their respective solvents to prepare a 2.0 mg mL−1 PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs alcoholic solution (ethanol) and a 2.0 mg mL−1 PVDF N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution. Subsequently, 900 µL of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs alcoholic solution was mixed evenly with 100 µL of the PVDF solution. Then, 1000 µL of the mixed solution was vacuum filtered onto a commercial PP separator until the mixed solution was completely drained. The obtained PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP functional separator was then vacuum dried at 70 °C for 5 h. A battery-punching machine was used to cut separators with a diameter of 18 mm for battery assembly. The synthesis method of CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP is the same as this. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterizations The brief synthesis strategy for the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material is illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). Initially, the necklace-like precursor material ZIF-67/CNTs was obtained by in-situ growth strategy based on acid-functionalized multi-walled CNTs. Characterization results of this precursor are presented in Supplementary Figs. S1–S3. Subsequently, the obtained precursor was selenized at high temperature in the atmosphere of argon gas. The cobalt source in the ZIF-67/CNTs was converted to CoSe2 nanoparticles in the presence of selenium powder, and the organic ligand was carbonized into NC skeleton coated outside the CoSe2 nanoparticles, resulting in the necklace-like CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite. Finally, a facile hydrothermal reaction was employed to load PMo12 onto the surfaces and/or cavities of the CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite, yielding the final PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material. The SEM image of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs is presented in Fig. 1(b). The assembly of PMo12/CoSe2@NC basically retains the polyhedral morphology of the initial ZIF-67, exhibiting an overall spherical resemblance. It can be observed that each assembly intertwines with CNTs, creating an interconnected network structure that could facilitate electron transport and thus contributing to improved cycling stability of the battery [59]. Notably, the PMo12 clusters are attached to surfaces and/or holes, but cannot be seen due to insufficient SEM resolution. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images in Fig. 1(c, d) show that the spherical PMo12/CoSe2@NC assemblies are connected in series by CNTs to form the necklace-like architecture, and there exist multiple small nano-particles in each assembly. As can be seen from Fig. S4, CoSe2@NC/CNTs maintained the same structure as PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. From the high-resolution (HR) TEM image in Fig. 1(e), lattice fringes with spacing distances of 2.90 and 2.59 Å correspond to the (101) and (111) crystal planes of CoSe2, respectively. Additionally, a lattice fringe with a spacing distance of 3.42 Å ascribed to the (222) plane of PMo12 also be observed [60,61], which confirms the successful loading of PMo12 nano-clusters onto the surface and/or cavities of the CoSe2@NC/CNTs material. Dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image and corresponding elemental mappings of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs (Fig. 1f–m) further underscore its necklace-like structure. The uniform fusion of Co and Se elements (Fig. 1g, h) reinforces the presence of the CoSe2 phase. Moreover, the homogeneous dispersion of P, Mo, and O elements (Fig. 1i–k) further indicates the effective incorporation of PMo12 nano-clusters within CoSe2@NC/CNTs, which is consistent with the HRTEM results. The existence of the NC framework and CNTs within the structure of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs is substantiated through the N and C elements mapping (Fig. 1l, m). The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite was directly drop-cast onto a conventional polypropylene (PP) separator, thereby establishing a modified physical barrier. It is well known that pure PP separator offers a network structure with interconnected large pores (∼100 nm) for the diffusion of ions and polysulfides, as depicted in Fig. S5a. In comparison to the conventional PP separator, the void spaces within the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator are entirely covered by the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs nanomaterial (Fig. S5b, c), resulting in a uniform surface without prominent large particles. As shown in Fig. S6, SEM measurements of the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibited analogous outcomes. Cross-sectional analysis (Fig. 1n) of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP reveals that the coating of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs nanocomposite adheres to one side of the PP separator with a thickness of ∼8 μm. As displayed in Fig. S7, the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibits similar coating thickness of ∼9 μm. As shown in Fig. 1(o), the coating of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibits sustained adhesion without delamination following folding, thereby signifying the exceptional adhesive and mechanical attributes inherent in the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator. From Fig. 1(p) and Fig. S8, it is evident that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators exhibit minimal visibility of electrolyte, indicating their pronounced wettability. In contrast, the pristine PP separator shows a notable presence of electrolyte (Fig. 1q). Moreover, the contact angles of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators are 3.88° and 6.52°, respectively, which are much lower than 53.12° of PP separator. The superior wettability is anticipated to expedite electrolyte penetration, facilitate Li+ migration, and enhance rate performance during cycling processes. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of PP, PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The results indicate the presence of characteristic peaks of PP and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs in the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator, confirming the existence of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs nanocomposite material on PP. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the PXRD pattern of CoSe2@NC/CNTs shows distinct diffraction peaks at 30.77°, 34.52°, and 47.72°, which correspond to the (1 0 1), (1 1 1), and (2 1 1) crystal planes of orthorhombic phase CoSe2 (PDF#53-0449), respectively. Notably, the broad peak attributed to carbon at around 25° is also observed in the PXRD pattern of CoSe2@NC/CNTs, which is consistent with the pure CNTs. In the PXRD pattern of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, the characteristic peaks attributed to CoSe2 and CNTs can be clearly observed. However, the diffraction peak of PMo12 is not obvious, only (2 2 0) and (2 2 2) faces of PMo12 (PDF#43-0314) can be faintly recognized at 21.18° and 26.03°, respectively. The low crystallinity of PMo12 indicates that it does not agglomerate together in large chunks, but is highly dispersed in the form of nano-clusters on the surface and/or cavity of CoSe2@NC/CNTs. The TGA curves of PMo12, CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs in air reflect the decomposition of NC species, PMo12 clusters, and the oxidation of CoSe2, as shown in Fig. 2(c). The PMo12 undergoes a decomposition process at approximately 100 °C, attributed to the loss of their crystalline water. Significant decomposition only starts at around 800 °C, indicating the excellent thermal stability of PMo12. Thermal decomposition of CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs both occur at around 300 °C, demonstrating their good thermal stability under battery testing temperatures. The final residual amounts of CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs are 18.76 and 26.17 wt%, respectively, reflecting that the host material in PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs is higher than that in CoSe2@NC/CNTs. This result further indicates the PMo12 clusters have been successfully attached onto CoSe2@NC/CNTs. Additionally, to further investigate the influence of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separators on Li+ transport channels and shuttle effect, analyses concerning the specific surface area and pore size distribution of PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators were conducted utilizing the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) methodology (Fig. 2d, e). According to the BET data analysis, the specific surface area of CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (25.1 m2 g−1) separator decreases obviously compared to pristine PP (67.1 m2 g−1), and the pore size is correspondingly reduced, which should be attributed to the CoSe2@NC/CNTs nano-composites blocking the large voids of the PP separator. As for PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separators, the specific surface area (20.7 m2 g−1) and pore size are further reduced due to the loading of PMo12 clusters. Therefore, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separators can effectively reduce the shuttling of LiPSs on the separators while ensuring Li+ transport. The chemical states of the elements in the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. As shown in Fig. 2(f), the full scan spectrum includes apparent signals of Mo, Co, Se, C, N, P, and O elements, reconfirming the chemical composition of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. The high-resolution spectra for different elements are presented in Fig. 2(g–i) and Fig. S9. As illustrated in Fig. 2(g), it can be observed that the Co 2p spectrum exhibits four peaks apart from the satellite peaks. The peaks at 796.48 and 780.88 eV correspond to Co2+ in Co 2p 1/2 and Co 2p 3/2 states, respectively, while the fitted peaks at 793.66 and 778.59 eV are attributed to Co3+ [62,63]. Fig. 2(h) distinctly displays that in the Se 3d spectrum, two characteristic peaks emerge for Se 3d 3/2 and Se 3d 5/2, with binding energies of 54.28 and 55.18 eV, respectively, revealing the presence of Se2− in CoSe2 [64]. Additionally, the minor peaks around 61.13 and 59.98 eV are attributed to inevitable oxidation of selenium at the edges [65]. Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 2(i), the Mo spectrum is characterized by a pair of peaks at 235.78 and 232.73 eV, which are indicative of Mo6+ [66,67]. These peaks originate from the surface and/or inner cavities of PMo12 clusters in MoSe2, further confirming their successful loading. The mass loading of PMo12 is calculated as 24.4% by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) test (Table S1). From Fig. S9a, the C 1s spectrum displays four distinct peaks corresponding to OCO at 287.49 eV, COC at 286.28 eV, CN at 285.52 eV, and CC/CC at 284.50 eV, indicating the presence of N heteroatoms. In the N 1s spectrum (Fig. S9b), three typical types of nitrogen atoms can be distinguished: graphitic nitrogen at 401.56 eV, pyrrolic nitrogen at 400.43 eV, and pyridinic nitrogen at 398.81 eV, corroborating the observations made in the C 1s spectrum [68]. A minor peak observed at 394.89 eV is attributed to Mo 3p [69], further proving the existence of PMo12. In Fig. S9c, the O 1s spectrum is resolved into four distinct single peaks. One peak at 529.99 eV corresponds to the MoO bond [70], originating from PMo12, reconfirming the anchor of PMo12 clusters on CoSe2@NC/CNTs composites, which is consistent with the information conveyed by the N 1s spectrum. The other three peaks correspond to COC (532.60 eV), COH (531.85 eV), and CO (530.93 eV), which is also consistent with the C 1s spectrum. 3.2 The conversion mechanism of polysulfide To demonstrate the anchoring effect of CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs on polysulfides, we conducted adsorption experiments by adding equal amounts of different samples into a medium-chain polysulfide solution (mainly Li2S4) [69]. The inset within Fig. 3 (a) presents optical images captured after 1 h of continuous stirring. The blank Li2S4/DME test solution typically appears yellow. In contrast, the significant discoloration of CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs can be clearly visualized, especially for PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. These experimental phenomena confirm that CoSe2 has relatively strong chemical adsorption capacity towards polysulfides and that PMo12 has a positive response in enhancing the adsorption capacity. The UV–vis test further substantiated the above inference (Fig. 3a). UV–visible spectra analysis of the resulting supernatant revealed a distinct characteristic peak at 417 nm in the blank Li2S4/DME solution, attributed to S4 2−. Interestingly, after the addition of CoSe2@NC/CNTs and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite materials, the characteristic peak almost disappeared, particularly after the addition of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. This further validates the strong interaction between polysulfides and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material, which is consistent with our hypothesis. We further performed XPS analysis on the adsorbed products to explore the specific adsorption mechanisms. The Li 1s spectrum of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs + Li2S4 is shown in Fig. 3(b). At 55.29 and 54.12 eV, the two fitted peaks correspond to the Li–S and Li–Se bonds, respectively. The presence of the Li–Se bond indicates a chemical interaction between the selenium sites in PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and the terminal lithium atoms in Li2S4 [64]. As seen in Fig. 3(c), high-resolution S 2p spectra can be attributed to bridging sulfur (SB 0) and terminal sulfur (ST −1) at 164.30/163.59 and 162.65/161.74 eV, respectively [71]. Compared to pure Li2S4, the relative intensity of SB 0 and ST −1 decreased after adding PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, indicating redox reactions between Li2S4 and the material. Notably, four peaks at 170.15, 168.96, 167.19, and 165.30 eV correspond to sulfate, polythionate, thiosulfate, and sulfite, respectively, suggesting that the polysulfides were oxidized to SO x [26,40,72]. Fig. 3(d) shows the Mo 3d spectra of pristine PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and after adsorption Li2S4. It can be observed that compared to the original PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, new characteristic peaks at 234.33 and 230.85 eV appeared after adsorbing Li2S4, which can be attributed to Mo4+. This indicates that some Mo6+ in the PMo12 clusters were reduced to Mo4+, confirming that PMo12 clusters is involved in the rapid oxidation of medium-chain LiPSs [26,40]. Meanwhile, subsequent to the adsorption of polysulfides, a distinct peak is observed at 227.94 eV, which should be primarily attributed to S 2s [73]. The valence state changes of Co further revealed the specific redox reaction between PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and Li2S4 (Fig. 3e). After adsorbing Li2S4, the ratio of Co3+ to Co2+ decreased from 0.246 to 0.212, reflecting that Co3+ was reduced to Co2+ to some extent, which is consistent with the aforementioned results. Additionally, the peaks of Co3+ and Co2+ shifted to relatively lower binding energies by approximately 0.42 and 0.68 eV, respectively. This observation could be associated with the robust bonding interaction between Co in CoSe2 and S in Li2S4 [64,74]. As shown in Fig. 3(f), a pair of new peaks appeared at 55.51 and 56.15 eV, corresponding to the Li–Se chemical bond, indicating that the Se2− in CoSe2 possesses good lithium affinity [65,75]. By summarizing these adsorption experiment results, it can be concluded that PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs exhibits strong chemical adsorption and catalytic activity towards soluble polysulfides, where CoSe2 plays a pivotal role in the chemical adsorption, and the PMo12 clusters and CoSe2 contribute to the acceleration of polysulfide conversion collectively. To intuitively verify the inhibitory effect of PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators on the diffusion of lithium polysulfides (Li2S4), an H-shaped tube was used [76]. In an experimental setup involving an H-tube, the right compartment was filled with DME solution, and the left compartment contained Li2S4 solution with the equivalent volume. Various separators, including PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, were situated in the middle to segregate the two solutions. Observations from Fig. S10 reveal that with the PP separator, Li2S4 solution began to diffuse after 1 h, and by 12 h, it had completely traversed to the right side. This indicates that the PP separator was ineffective in curbing the polysulfides' shuttle effect. For the H-tube with CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator, permeation began after 6 h, and partial permeation occurred after 12 h (Fig. 3g), indicating that the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator had a certain inhibitory effect on polysulfides. However, the right side of the H-tube with PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator remained transparent and slightly permeable after 12 h (Fig. 3h), proving that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator could effectively inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides. Li2S nucleation experiments provided insights into the redox kinetics associated with the liquid–solid transformation of LiPSs to Li2S (Fig. S11). Notably, the Li2S precipitation capacity on the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs-modified separator was calculated to be 265.2 mA h gsulfur −1 (Fig. S11a), surpassing the 221.9 mA h gsulfur −1 observed on the PP separator (Fig. S11b). These findings demonstrate that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs catalyst significantly enhances the liquid–liquid and liquid–solid conversion processes of LiPSs [48]. To get a comprehensively understand the mechanism of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs catalyst in catalyzing the redox kinetics of LiPSs in LSBs, we analyzed the conversion process of sulfur intermediates during the discharge/charge process using in-situ ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy. During the discharge–charge process at 0.02C, between 1.8 and 2.8 V, the in-situ UV–visible spectra of S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs and S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs were recorded (Fig. 4 a, b) [69]. Compared to the S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs electrode (discharge specific capacity ≈ 728.03 mA h g−1, discharge time ≈ 22 h), the S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs electrode displays higher discharge specific capacity and discharge time (discharge specific capacity ≈ 854.03 mA h g−1, discharge time ≈ 28 h). In the course of charging, the electrode composed of S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs exhibited a charge-specific capacity approximately equal to 610.15 mA h g−1 over a duration close to 18 h. This performance surpasses that of the S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs electrode, which demonstrated a capacity of 488.63 mA h g−1 within a 14-h charging period. These findings suggest that PMo12 clusters play a pivotal role in catalyzing the interconversion between soluble LiPSs and the insoluble compound lithium sulfide (Li2S) [69]. Various LiPSs species (S4 2−, S6 2−, S8 2−, S3 −) are represented using different qualitative colors [77]. Throughout the entire discharge process, the S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs cathode exhibits higher concentration of long-chain polysulfides (S6 2− and S8 2−) than the control cathode of S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs. This phenomenon is likely attributed to the redox interactions occurring between PMo12 nano-clusters and LiPSs. Such interactions are conducive to the improvement of sulfur utilization efficiency within the system. Notably, the in-situ Li-S visual colorimetric cell with the S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs cathode consistently shows a higher concentration of sulfur tri-radical (S3 −) than that of S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs cathode, indicating that PMo12 could effectively promote the dissociation reaction of S6 2− (S6 2− → 2S3 −) [78]. As known to all, the presence of high concentration of S3 − is beneficial to the formation of additional reducible LiPSs and the reduction of solid sulfur (2S3 − + 1/4S8 → S8 2−) [79], thus further contributes to the improvement of reaction kinetics. Additionally, during the charging process, the re-emergence and increase of S4 2−, S6 2−, S8 2− and S3 − were observed. Compared to the S@CoSe2@NC/CNTs electrode, the S@PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs cathode exhibits higher concentration of S6 2− and S3 −, indicating that the PMo12 clusters effectively promote the oxidation of insoluble Li2S. Based on the above discussion, it can be stated that the bidirectional reactions of LiPSs reduction and Li2S oxidation can be effectively catalyzed with the PMo12 nano-clusters of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, thus resulting in the enhancement of the redox kinetics of lithium-sulfur batteries. To further elucidate the interactions between CoSe2, PMo12 nano-clusters and polysulfides, DFT calculations were also employed. The optimized CoSe2 and PMo12 were optimized with Li2S4, which is representative of the polysulfides. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), Co in the (1 0 0) plane of CoSe2-Co can be chemically bonded to S atoms in Li2S4 with a binding energy (E b) of −4.39 eV. At the same time, Se in the (1 0 0) plane of CoSe2-Se can be chemically combined with Li in Li2S4, and its E b is −2.06 eV (Fig. 5b). These binding energy data prove the strong chemical adsorption capacity of CoSe2 on LiPSs. As indicated in Fig. 5(c), there exist LiO and LiMo bonds between the oxygen/molybdenum atoms in the PMo12 nano-clusters and the lithium atoms in Li2S4, and the binding energy between PMo12 and Li2S4 is calculated to be −1.72 eV, demonstrating the moderate binding affinity of PMo12 clusters towards LiPSs. To further validate the catalytic conversion capability of PMo12 cluster, we conducted analyses of the Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) and Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital (LUMO) distributions, illustrated in Fig. 5(d, e). The HOMO is predominantly located on the polysulfide surface, suggesting a propensity for electron loss in this system, whereas the LUMO, characterized by a strong electron-accepting capability, is distributed on the surface of the PMo12 cluster. These results are consistent with our conjecture and in-situ UV test results, affirming the catalytic role of PMo12 clusters in the transformation of polysulfides [48]. In addition, the electron band structures (Fig. 5f, g) and state density (DOS) (Fig. 5h, i) of PMo12 clusters and CoSe2 were calculated. As shown in Fig. 5(f, g), PMo12 has a wide band gap of 2.3 eV, while CoSe2 has a narrower band gap of 1.3 eV. As shown in Fig. 5(h), the DOS of PMo12 exhibits a lack of states near the Fermi level, indicating poor conductivity. This is because PMo12, a polyoxometalate (POM), typically behaves as an insulator or a poor semiconductor with limited charge carrier availability. Its electronic states are insufficient to facilitate efficient electron transport. In Fig. 5(i), the DOS of CoSe2 shows a significant number of states near the Fermi level, which is characteristic of semiconductors or materials with good electronic conductivity. CoSe2, as a transition metal dichalcogenide, has an electronic structure that allows for moderate charge carrier mobility. The results suggest that combining PMo12 with CoSe2 can synergistically improve the electrical conductivity of the composite. CoSe2 compensates for PMo12's poor conductivity by providing additional electronic states near the Fermi level, enabling more efficient electron transfer throughout the composite material. The low band gap makes it easier for electrons to transition in energy levels, thereby improving the overall electrical conductivity of the material. 3.3 Electrochemical performance CR2032 type coin cells were assembled using lithium foil as the anode and S/CNTs as the cathode material, and the electrochemical performance of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator and other separators, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and PP, were evaluated. The sulfur loading of each cathode sheet is approximately 1.2 mg cm−2. Fig. 6 (a) illustrates the cyclic voltammetry profiles (CVs) for the initial four cycles of a Li-S battery, which employs a PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator. These CV measurements were conducted at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. Remarkably, two distinct reduction peaks can be observed within regions I and II. These peaks are indicative of the reduction process of elemental sulfur (S8) into lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) (S8 + 4e− → 2S4 2−) and the subsequent transformation of soluble LiPSs to insoluble lithium sulfides (Li2S2/Li2S) (2S4 2− + 12e− → 8S2−), requiring 4 and 12 electrons transfer, respectively. Integration calculations reveal that, in the first CV cycle, the area ratio of the two reduction peaks (A2/A1) is approximately 2.924, close to the theoretical value of 3. For the charging process (Ⅲ), two oxidation peaks are observed, corresponding to the gradual transformation of insoluble Li2S to LiPSs, and further oxidation to S8 [80]. The sum of the areas of the oxidation peaks (A3 = 1.103) is roughly consistent with the total area of the aforementioned two reduction peaks (A1 + A2 = 1.079), revealing good reversibility during the battery's charge–discharge process [71]. Additionally, the CVs of the second cycle and subsequent cycles overlap well, further demonstrating that the electrochemical reactions of the battery equipped with PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator are highly reversible and exhibit relatively good capacity retention [49]. Similarly, the CVs of the first four cycles for CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and PP are also recorded and display shapes nearly identical to the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator (Fig. S12). Fig. S13a compares the CV curves of the first cycle of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PP. Empirical observations delineate a sequential decrease in oxidation voltage across PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separators. Conversely, the reduction voltage exhibits a corresponding increase in this sequence. This trend suggests that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator demonstrates the smallest polarization, alongside the fastest reaction kinetics. Simultaneously, the strongest current of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator further indicates its rapid sulfur redox kinetics [81]. In addition, The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibited a significantly higher current density compared to the pure PP separator. (Fig. S14) This observation demonstrates that the incorporation of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs enhances electrocatalytic activity and accelerates the redox reactions. Such improvements are typically attributed to the composite's ability to enhance sulfur adsorption, facilitate lithium polysulfide (LiPS) conversion, and improve electron transfer efficiency. Furthermore, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator displayed a lower overpotential than the pure PP separator, indicating a reduced energy barrier for redox reactions. Collectively, these findings underscore the catalytic role of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs in promoting more efficient polysulfide conversion compared to the unmodified PP separator. An investigation employing Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) was performed to garner enhanced dynamic insights into the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PP separators. Analysis of the Nyquist plots, as depicted in Fig. S13b, reveals a characteristic semi-circle in the high to medium frequency domain, complemented by a linear segment in the low-frequency range. The observed semi-circle is indicative of the resistance at the electrolyte/electrode interface (R s) coupled with the charge transfer resistance (R ct). In contrast, the linear trajectory in the plots is indicative of Li+ diffusion, commonly referred to as Warburg impedance (W 0) [23,82]. As shown in Fig. S15 and Table S2, the equivalent circuits and equivalent circuit parameters corresponding to these separators are provided. The R ct of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP is 34.22 Ω, which is significantly lower than that of CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (60.28 Ω) and PP (139.05 Ω). This result suggests that the unique composition and architecture of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs coating can notably enhance the electron transfer capability during the lithiation process, thereby improving the battery performance. In situ-EIS is a powerful electrochemical technique that provides insights into the electrochemical impedance of lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) at various depths of discharge (DOD), as shown in the Fig. S16. As illustrated in the figure, at lower voltages (e.g., 1.7 V), the observed larger semicircle corresponds to a higher R ct, reflecting the slower redox kinetics associated with the initial sulfur reduction process. As the voltage increases (e.g., 2.4 V), the semicircle becomes smaller, indicating improved charge transfer and accelerated reaction kinetics. The formation of soluble long-chain lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), such as Li2S6 and Li2S8, contributes to an increase in electrolyte viscosity, which subsequently influences lithium-ion conductivity [72]. Fig. 6(b) presents the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) plots of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PP separators at 0.1C. Notably, compared with CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (ΔE = 0.349 V) and PP (ΔE = 0.382 V), the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator consistently exhibits a smaller voltage gap (ΔE = 0.225 V) both between working and equilibrium states and on the charge/discharge plateaus. This indicates a reduction in the voltage hysteresis of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, attributed to its high conductivity and catalytic ability, enhancing the redox reaction kinetics [83]. Fig. S13c displays the galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator under various current densities, revealing two typical discharge plateaus, consistent with the CV results. Similarly, the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and PP separators also exhibit two discharge plateaus under various current densities, as shown in Fig. S17. As illustrated in Fig. S13d, compared with CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (ΔE = 0.141 V) and PP (ΔE = 0.211 V), the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator displays a relatively lower voltage hysteresis (ΔE = 0.093 V). These results are consistent with the conclusions drawn from other electrochemical performance analyses, indicating that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs surface possesses a lower kinetic barrier between S8 and Li2S2/Li2S and enhanced catalytic conversion ability. The rate performance of the separators of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and PP were systematically evaluated. This assessment involved progressively escalating the current rate from 0.1 to 5.0C across intervals of ten cycles, followed by a reversion to 0.1C, as detailed in Fig. 6(c) and Table S3. Initial discharge specific capacities for the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator at various C-rates (0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5C) were recorded as 1263.79, 1172.84, 1130.95, 1103.15, 1034.67, 952.30, 902.19, and 796.82 mA h g−1, respectively. Remarkably, the separator achieved a specific capacity of 796.82 mA h g−1 at 5C, representing 47.33% of its theoretical capacity (1675 mA h g−1), which suggests effective sulfur utilization at high C-rates. Upon reverting to a 0.1C rate, the separator maintained a substantial specific capacity of 894.48 mA h g−1. Furthermore, when compared to the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP and PP separators, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator exhibited superior initial specific capacities at various current densities (as listed in Table S3). Above findings underscore the efficacy of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite coating in enhancing the rate performance of the separator. The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PP separators were assembled into button cells and their long cycling performance was tested at 1C, as shown in Fig. 6(d). Consistent with the rate performance results, the battery incorporating the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibited a higher initial discharge capacity of 1049.60 mA h g−1 than those incorporating CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (899.02 mA h g−1) and PP (632.34 mA h g−1) separators. Impressively, the capacity of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP was largely retained over extended use, with a recorded capacity of 747.64 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles. This performance translates to a remarkably low capacity decay rate of merely 0.09% per cycle. Concurrently, the battery demonstrated a consistently high Coulombic efficiency (CE), approximately 99%, throughout the cycling process, indicative of its robust cycle reversibility [84]. The battery assembled with CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator demonstrated similar long cycling performance, which should possibly due to the superior adsorption capacity towards polysulfides of CoSe2 phase. In contrast, the capacity for the battery with the PP separator experienced a pronounced decline, dropping to 465.93 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles, primarily due to the uncontrolled diffusion of soluble LiPSs into the electrolyte. Intriguingly, even under the stress of a higher current density of 3C, as delineated in Fig. 6(e), the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator maintained commendable cycling stability. Its initial discharge capacity was recorded at 635.77 mA h g−1, with a minimal capacity decay per cycle of 0.06% after 500 cycles. To bring the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator closer to practical applications in LSBs, the electrochemical performance was also investigated at a high sulfur loading of 3.2 mg cm−2. As can be seen from Fig. 6(f), at high sulfur loading, the initial discharge capacities of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator at different C-rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, and 1C were 1067.94, 1020.89, 963.88, 867.67, and 709.03 mA h g−1, respectively. Interestingly, when the C-rate was brought back to 0.1C, its discharge capacity could reach 1009.55 mA h g−1, equivalent to 94.53% of the initial discharge capacity. All the charge–discharge profiles of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator measured from 0.1 to 1C showed two typical reaction plateaus (Fig. S18). When the assembled cell was cycled at 1C, after 150 cycles, the discharge capacity slowly decreased from 733.62 to 555.26 mA h g−1 (Fig. 6g). Meanwhile, a CE of about 93% could be observed. These results indicate that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibits satisfactory electrochemical performance at high sulfur loading. As shown in the Fig. S19a, The PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP-modified separator was incorporated into a Li-S pouch cells with a high sulfur loading of 4.2 mg cm−2, corresponding to a total sulfur mass of approximately 83 mg. This Li-S pouch cells successfully powered a red LED (Fig. S19b), demonstrating its ability to operate at a high voltage. At a current rate of 0.5C, the battery achieved a peak discharge capacity of 467 mA h g−1, and after 100 cycles, it retained a relatively stable discharge capacity of 356 mA h g−1, the attenuation rate per turn is 0.235%, highlighting its excellent cycling stability. Data presented in Fig. 6(h) and Table S4, offer a comprehensive overview of the cycling stability characteristics exhibited by various modified separators when integrated within LSBs. In comparison, in terms of electrochemical stability, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibits competitive battery performance in key parameters in LSBs, demonstrating significant advantages [32,50,85–92]. To investigate the impact of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator on the morphology of deposited lithium, SEM and EDX characterizations were performed on the lithium metal anode before and after long cycling. As shown in Fig. S20, the initial surface of the lithium metal anode is smooth and flat. However, after 200 cycles at 1C, the surface of the lithium anode with PP separator becomes rough with obvious accumulation of LiPSs (Li2S2/Li2S) and irregular lithium dendrites (Fig. 7 a), indicating that LiPSs can easily react with lithium metal through the PP separator, demonstrating that the PP separator does not prevent the shuttling effect of LiPSs [93]. As depicted in Fig. 7(b), after 200 cycles with CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator, the surface of the lithium anode exhibits a loose porous structure and cracks, with no obvious Li2S2/Li2S deposition. When using the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP composite separator, the surface of the lithium metal is relatively smooth (Fig. 7c), as it can regulate the Li+ flux and induce uniform lithium nucleation, indicating that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites [93]. Subsequently, EDX analysis was conducted on the surface of the three different lithium metal anodes (insets of Fig. 7a–c), showing that after using PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators, the sulfur intensity on the lithium anode surface decreased sequentially, further confirming that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material can suppress the shuttling effect of LiPSs. As displayed in Fig. 7(d–f), SEM cross-sectional images indicate that the lithium deposition thickness on the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator (75 μm) is smaller than that on the CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP (87 μm) and PP (110 μm) separators, suggesting that the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material can reduce lithium deposition on the metal surface. To further verify the protective effect of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP on the lithium anode, Li|Li symmetric cells were assembled with PP, CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, and PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separators (Fig. 7g), respectively, and their lithium plating/stripping performance was studied under a constant current of 1 mA cm−2. Compared to PP and CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator assembled Li|Li symmetric cell exhibits a lower overpotential of ∼40 mV, and maintains a stable overpotential after 500 h, demonstrating its unique superiority in inhibiting lithium dendrite growth [94,95]. In addition, a series of characterizations of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator were performed after 200 cycles at 1C. The SEM image (Fig. S21) show that the surface of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs is rougher than at the beginning, which should be attributed to the polysulfide adsorption. As illustrated in Fig. 7(h) and Fig. S22, the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy elemental mapping and TEM image reveal the structural integrity of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs, with no damage or dissolution of the structure during charging and discharging. Notably, the elemental mapping shows a uniform distribution of sulfur elements on the surface of the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs composite material, providing strong evidence for the capability to capture LiPSs of PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs. It is worth mentioning that the molybdenum element is also evenly distributed on the surface of the composite material, indicating that PMo12 clusters still exist on the surface of the material stably after cycling. To summarize, a catalytic scheme for the multi-electron reaction catalyzed by PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs in a LSB system was proposed (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator establishes an effective physical barrier between the cathode and anode. Secondly, CoSe2 possesses strong chemical adsorption capacity for soluble polysulfides, significantly suppressing the shuttle effect. Thirdly, the PMo12 nano-clusters can rapidly catalyze the bidirectional conversion of sulfur. Last but not the least, the network structure formed by the NC framework and CNTs facilitate the rapid transmission of lithium ions and enhances the electrical conductivity of the material. This holistic approach not only addresses the conductivity and mechanical integrity of the battery but also tackles the notorious shuttle effect, enhances the redox kinetics and inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites. 4 Conclusions In summary, POM nano-clusters was successfully combined with CoSe2 nano-particles to obtain novel PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP modified separator for advanced LSBs. The CoSe2 phase was primarily responsible for the adsorption of LiPSs, while the PMo12 nano-clusters mainly contributed to the bidirectional catalytic conversion of sulfur. Thanks to the synergistic effect between PMo12 nano-clusters and CoSe2 nano-particles, such modified separator effectively inhibits the shuttle effect, accelerates the conversion of polysulfides and prevents the growth of lithium dendrites. Meanwhile, the porous skeleton composed of NC framework and CNTs endowed PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs with high electrical conductivity and rapid electron and lithium ion transfer channels. The individual roles of PMo12 and CoSe2 during charge and discharge processes were carefully determined through a series of adsorption tests, electrochemical measurements, H-tube experiments, in-situ characterizations and DFT calculations. When applied to the separator of LSBs, the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs/PP separator exhibited a high initial capacity of 1263.79 mA h g−1 at 0.1C and cycling stability (providing a specific capacity of approximately 635.77 mA h g−1 at 3C, with a capacity decay rate of 0.06% per cycle after 500 cycles). This research integrates nanomaterial design with POMs modifications, offering a valuable approach for the preparation of high-performance separators for LSBs. Moreover, this method provides fresh insights into potential applications in other advanced energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: The polysulfides shuttle effect, sluggish sulfur redox kinetics and the corrosion of the Li anode have become important factors limiting the commercial application of lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs). Herein, the polyoxometalate (POM) nanoclusters with high catalytic activity and cobalt selenide with strong polarity are initially complemented to construct a PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs multifunctional separator that can simultaneously solve the above problems. A series of experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the Keggin-type POM, H3PMo12O40·nH2O (PMo12) nanoclusters could function as catalytic centers for sulfur-involved transformations, with the CoSe2 nanoparticles serving as adsorption sites for soluble polysulfides. Accordingly, the assembled battery with the PMo12/CoSe2@NC/CNTs modified separator achieves an initial discharge capacity of 1263.79 mA h g−1, maintaining 635.77 mA h g−1, with a capacity decay rate of 0.06% per cycle after 500 cycles at 3C. This work provides a strategic approach for incorporating POM nanoclusters with polar periodic nanomaterials in LSB separators, contributing to the development of multifunctional separator materials, thus promoting the advancement of energy storage systems.
